Emergency Response Program
Los Angeles Cold Storage has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for the purpose of protecting employees and the surrounding community.  The EAP covers procedures for: 1) evacuating and accounting for visitors and employees, 2) dealing with an ammonia release and other foreseeable emergencies that could occur onsite, 3) notifying external agencies and emergency response personnel, and 4) administering first aid measures for ammonia exposure.  Employees are informed of the elements of the EAP.  In the event of an ammonia release, employees will evacuate or shelter-in-place, depending on the nature of the release, and the facility will contact the fire department for assistance as necessary.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety
A Process Hazard Analysis has been performed on the ammonia system, and this study resulted in action items to improve safety at the facility.  The recommendations mainly consist of formalizing procedures, implementing practices consistent with industry standards, and performing inspections and tests to maintain the integrity of the equipment.  Los Angeles Cold Storage has implemented several of these action items and is moving forward with completing the remaining outstanding recommendations.   In addition, the facility plans to continue providing employees with a safe work environment through continued training on current policies and procedures, and conducting audits to identify deficiencies and make improvements.

Accidental Release and Emergency Response Policies
Los Angeles Cold Storage is committed to providing a safe environment to its employees and surrounding communities.  This commitment is reflected in the safety and environmental programs that are implemented at the facility.  For example, written procedures have been created for operating the ammonia refrigeration system.  Only trained operators are permitted to perform system operations.  Los Angeles Cold Storage has also developed a robust maintenance program to ensure the equipment is in good operating condition and maintenance is also performed by the refrigeration contractor.  All of these programs are geared towards the prevention of an accidental release at the facility.  In addition, these programs incorporate emergency procedures to mitigate the effects of a release if it does occur.  At such an event, emergency coordinators will assess the situation and notify outside responding agencies as necessary.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Los Angeles Cold Storage is located at 400 South Central Avenue in Los Angeles, California.  Ammonia is used in the facility’s refrigeration system to provide cooling for the storage of various food products.  The system uses a maximum of 32,908 pounds of ammonia.  A description of how the process operates is presented below: 

Liquid ammonia in the high pressure receiver is fed to the intercooler and recirculators.  The recirculators pump liquid to the evaporators.  At the evaporators, air is drawn over the coils by the evaporator fans.  The ammonia flowing inside the coils is partially vaporized as it absorbs heat from the surrounding air.  The partially vaporized ammonia is returned to the recirculator, where the liquid settles at the bottom of the vessel, while the vapor rises to the top.
